title: 111_hr2134
content: The Act may be cited as the "Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission Act of 2009". The Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration's National Survey on Drug Use and Health in 2008 estimated millions of users of marijuana, cocaine, methamphetamine, and heroin in the United States. The majority of cocaine and heroin supply in the US originates from Andean countries and Colombia and Mexico, respectively, leading to violence, instability, and corruption. Drug trafficking in Central America, Mexico, and other countries poses a threat to law enforcement, political institutions, and US security interests. Drug-related violence is increasing in Mexico and along the US-Mexico border, with 5,661 deaths in 2008 alone. Organized criminal networks in Mexico traffic women and girls into the US for sexual exploitation. Extremist groups like FARC and Hezbollah use drug trafficking to fund terrorist activities. US counternarcotics assistance to Latin America and the Caribbean totaled $11.3 billion from 1980-2008. The Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission is established to review and evaluate US policies on illicit drug supply reduction and interdiction, focusing on international drug policies in the Western Hemisphere. The Commission will identify options to improve existing counternarcotics policies. The Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission will review US policies on illicit drug supply reduction, interdiction, and demand reduction. It will assess international drug control policies, drug interdiction efforts, technology deployment against drug cartels, and efforts to curb drug trafficking. The Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission will assess the United States drug certification process, population's demand for illicit drugs, prevention and treatment programs, addiction treatment effectiveness, and recommendations for improving drug policies. It will also evaluate support for government and nongovernmental institutions in other countries. The Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission will assess the United States drug control policy, consult with various stakeholders in the Western Hemisphere, and submit a report to the relevant committees in Congress within 12 months of its first meeting. The Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission will submit a report to relevant congressional committees containing recommendations, findings, and conclusions, as well as input from consulted leaders and organizations. The report will be made available to the public. The report will be made available to the public. SEC. 6. MEMBERSHIP. The Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission is composed of ten members appointed by various leaders, excluding current government officials. Each member serves for the life of the Commission, with vacancies filled promptly. Appointments must be made within 30 days of the Act's enactment, and an initial meeting to plan the review process must occur within 60 days. The Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission consists of ten members who appoint a Chairperson at the initial meeting. Six members form a quorum, and members receive travel expenses as per regulations while performing Commission services. Six members form a quorum, and members receive travel expenses as per regulations while performing Commission services. SEC. 7. POWERS. The Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission has the authority to hold meetings and hearings as needed. They also have access to necessary resources from various government agencies and are provided with office space and administrative support by the General Services Administration. The Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission has the authority to use the United States mails and enter into contracts for necessary activities. Contracts cannot extend beyond the Commission's termination date. SEC. 8. STAFF. The Commission shall have an Executive Director who can appoint necessary staff and procure services as needed. Staff compensation shall not exceed level V of the Executive Schedule. The Commission may request Federal agencies to detail personnel to assist in its duties under section 3109(b) of title 5, United States Code, without affecting their civil service status or privileges. Authorization of $2,000,000 for the Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission without fiscal year limitation. Commission terminates 60 days after report submission to Congress.
